paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the V122I mutation in the TTR gene, its prevalence in African Americans with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, and provides penetrance data for affected and unaffected carriers.

patients.demographics: Both patients were women in their sixth decade of life.
patients.phenotype: Both patients had the V122I mutation; one reported symptoms of cardiomyopathy.

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The one with homozygous mutation reported symptoms of cardiomyopathy but had no specific diagnosis.
The other was heterozygous, and the other had a diagnosis of hypothyroidism.

functional_data.summary: The functional impact of the V122I mutation on TTR protein stability and amyloid formation is implied but not directly studied in this paper.

variants.population_frequency: 3-4% in the general African American population.
variants.evidence_level: Moderate evidence based on prevalence and clinical presentation.
variants.additional_notes: The study suggests that the presence of bilateral CTS may justify screening for the TTR mutation.
key_quotes: Two of the 16 patients (12.5%) had the V122I TTR mutation.
Both were women and in the sixth decade of life.

tables_processed.table_caption: Results of TTR mutation screening, with red flag symptom, CTS risk factors, and family history of CTS and cardiomyopathy.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the TTR gene and its variants were extracted accurately.
